title: Where can I find royalty-free background music for inclusion in videos and short films? - Quora

response.answer_text: How To Get Royalty Free Music For Your YouTube Videos  In this piece, we will look at five places you can get royalty free songs to use in your online videos YouTube Audio Library - YouTube provides its users with a huge selection of royalty free music at no cost. The licenses for some tracks require artist attribution, which means you need to credit to the original band or artist. Music which requires attribution is clearly labelled. All of the music in YouTube’s library is sorted by genre, so you can easily browse for certain kinds of music. You can even favorite songs you like so you can find them again quickly. Besides music, the YouTube Audio Library also includes royalty free sound effects. The songs in YouTube’s library are for both non-commercial and commercial use. FreePD - On http://www.FreePD.com they have collected a large number of songs considered public domain. This means that artists have chosen to give up their ownership rights. While royalty free songs will sometimes be accidentally flagged by YouTube for copyright infractions this is far less likely to happen when you use music that is public domain. It costs $14 to download FreePD’s entire library. AudioJungle - Royalty Free Music & Audio from AudioJungle has a large selection of royalty free music and sound effects which you can buy either one at a time or in themed packages. An individual song can cost anywhere from $7 to $19 dollars. You will be able to use music from AudioJungle in your online video project without restriction with their standard license, but there are different levels of licensing for television and other mediums which will increase your price. MusicBed - Over 650 indie musicians and composers have contributed to the library on Musicbed. Pricing and licensing depends on the song, what you want to use it for, and how big your company is. Getting music from MusicBed could turn into more of an investment, but it could be a worthwhile investment. The music has all been created by professional musicians. Marmoset - The music on Marmoset // Meticulously curated music for licensing costs quite a bit more than on a lot of the other sites listed in this article. A Small Business License costs a minimum of $199, and could end up being $999 depending on how large the business is. The costs are lower for non-commercial uses, but they are still quite a bit more than on a site like AudioJungle. A Home Video license, for example, is $69. The music on Marmoset has all been curated by professional musicians, so you are guaranteed quality. You can even have tracks customized, or have a completely original score crafted for your video content. It’s important to remember that when music is royalty free, it means that the copyright holder has decided to allow video creators to use their work if they get a license for it. Licenses can be free, or they can cost money. How much a license costs, and what its conditions are, varies depending on where you get your music. The most common licensing condition is attribution – giving credit to the artist. Since royalty free music is still protected by copyright, YouTube’s automated system may still flag music you have a license to use. Disputing the claim and getting your video restored is usually fairly simple. There are a lot of places you can go online to find great royalty free music for your YouTube projects. Given the quantity of music available it should be possible for you to find the absolute perfect songs for your videos. It just takes some searching. There is a wide range of pricing, and pricing is often dependent on factors such as how large your brand is. While quality songs are available for free, you may find that your perfect soundtrack is a bit of an investment. It is even possible to have unique music created for you, if you are willing to pay for something like that.

Most of the time it is not really the issue of royalty fee, but is the licensing fee. There is a distinction between the two: Royalty fee: relates very much to the exposure the final work. For example, if you're using the background music for a YouTube video, the royalty fee would be affected by the number of views the video will eventually get. You'll need to pay more if the video gets more views.Licensing fee: refers to the compensation you pay to the artist for a licensed use of his/her copywrited music, the amount depends largely on what the music will be used for (i.e. whether personal, commercial, local, global, etc. ) and sometimes are paid on a per year basis (instead of a one-off, use-forever payment). If you google for royalty-free music, you'll indeed find many sites offering that. But do read the fine print. Because:A. "free to download" does not mean you're free to use it wherever. Some sites run on an honor code basis, meaning they'll allow you to download (for free) the full track so that you can test out the product, if and when you've decided to use the track in your final works (e.g. video, presentation, etc.), you then purchase a license for that particular use.B. "Royalty-free" does not mean at no cost. It just means that they don't charge any royalty fee for the track. So it make more sense to say "free royalty-free music", if you don't want to pay a dime. But then..C. "Licensing fee". Licensing fee is usually the final but most important (cause it's usually the priciest) element you need to look out for. Some sites are more upfront/clear/visible about the fact that they charge licensing fee and also provide a clear pricing structure. Others (a larger portion unfortunately) are not so. Its hidden in their FAQ list or another page called "license" which is only visible if you scroll down all the way to the footer (and its not on footer of all the pages). You get the idea. This info is collected from researching to curate audio sites for YouTube videos. The tracks you find are usually music, sound effects or loops. If you're interested to read about the pros and cons of the sites I've encountered, check it out @youtuberboss.
